en: Interview with Bob Sweeney, resident of Gatlinburg. Sweeney describes the fire as a someone who recently moved to the area before suffering losses. He recounts the following days and months in terms of the lessons he learned from the wildfire and the opportunities that it provided. This is a representative quote from the interview: We look over and there's a a flower pot with some pansies still planted in it that was untouched. And there were a few items like that just scattered around, a bench over here that didn't burn. And I think we went over and we kind of talked about how funny that was. And we were just kind of skirting around the fact that there wasn't any house there, and all of that I guess. You just kind of push yourself over into a safer place for a minute.
Individuals (tourists or locals) directly affected by the fire

Can you state your name and tell us about yourself?
How long have you been in Gatlinburg?
Had you been visiting Gatlinburg as a family?
Can you tell us a little about your family?
Where did you live in relation to downtown Gatlinburg before the fire?
What's it like living in a town like Gatlinburg with a small local population but a large tourist presence?
Can you talk about the Summer and Fall before the fire?
Your son had mentioned that it was his birthday a few days before the fire?
What did you experience the day of the fire?
What time were you talking with your wife about what to take when evacuating?
At what point did you decide to leave for Gatlinburg from West Tennessee?
What was it like that night when you reunited with your family?
How long were you at your friends' house?
What was it like going back to your home for the first time?
Was it within those following three days that you decided to go to your home?
Can you tell us about the months after the fire?
Were you also in the camper for Christmas?

seo.title: Interview with Bob Sweeney, 2020-03-14 - Rising From the Ashes Oral Histories
